Floral notes in the sinuses. Creamy mouthfeel with a dry end. If anyone here besides me has consumed rose petals, this is quite similar. Pleasant, melancholy and (dare I say) gothic. 


Bridgeview Liquors, Bridgeview, IL
Staple for the style. If SNPA is the textbook pale ale, this is certainly the texbook wit. Decent, enjoyable and well made... but not mindblowing.

I really enjoyed this one, served in a huge glass, takes awhile to drink, great taste, can taste the orange, with a bit of sweetness, great color, a bit white and amber combined, interesting appearance
Cloudy pale yellow body with average white head.  Light grass, lemon citrus aroma and slight sour, lime flavor.  Smooth body, sweet finish.  Refreshing drinking beer.

This cloudy golden wheat beer poured with a nice white head, eliciting a pleasant spicy aroma. The flavor is a bit fruity and heavily spiced. This is a very refreshing drink that goes well on a hot summer day.
Although cloudy, I found the appearance appealing. Great head properties. Lots of aroma. A big bouquet of flavours across the palate - lots of fruitiness, yet quite smooth. Give me another!
By far the best of the summer beers. Crisp and refreshing. Goes great with seafood dishes.

A yummy wheat beer-very good for the summer.  I had this one on tap and fortunately I did not get an orange in it when it was served to me.  Nice frtuiy aroma.  It was a cloudy lemony color with a nice white head.  This one was very easy to drink.

A solid witbier. Although I get a little upset every time I order a draft, and the bartender places an orange in it. Nice cloudy golden color with some floaties. The head is a bright white and very creamy. Aroma is of wheat and citrus (even without the orange). Wheat is defintely present, and so is lemon and some spice, which rounds out the aftertaste. It is a light verison of a witbier, but still solid noetheless, perfect for a warm summer day.

Tap. Nice aroma. I enjoy wheat beers in the summertime but I was a bit disappointed with this one. The flavor was a bit light. Some nutmeggy spiciness but I probably wouldn’t buy it again. A lot of hype and not a lot of flavor.

Strong wheaty aroma. Big creamy head that tastes very smooth on the tongue and gives a milk-mustache (beer mustache?). Taste was not as enjoyable as the aroma. Mostly reminiscent of a hefe, with a bit of spice. Palete was a bit thin for my tastes.

Bottle. Pours a very light hazy color. Big foamy white head. Big grainy/yeasty aroma with a hint of lemon. Slighly sweet flavor. Mild flavor of a hefe. A touch of spice and a slightly bitter finish. Goes down quite easily but I wouldn’t get too excited about this stuff.

This was a very average beer, especially for its price. It was too light and seemed like an America light in the form of a white. However, it still had a decent smell and appearance. Nevertheless, its taste was very ordinary.  The Allagash White is a better offering in my opinion.

Draught at The Half Moon in Putney, a cloudy and very pale yellow with a white foamy head.  Aroma is a tangy orange, maybe some corriander, but more sweet and yeastish.  Over-carbonated in the mouth, with a sharp and tart palate. The citrus and wheat flavours that do get through are pleasing however.

On tap on McGrady’s Pub, I have to say up front I was well into the night when I had this and was feeling good.  That being said..Aroma was nice, orange not too sweet.  Appeared a hazy yellow like lemonade. Flavor was airy citrus and spice. Sugary light palate.  Very refreshing.  I really enjoyed it. Don’t forget to ditch the lemon they serve with it.

Nicely hazy, not overly cloudy yellow, big white bottle conditioned head, leaving a nice lace, nice steady fine bubbled bead. Interesting nose...spice/yeast/citrus fruit very nice  and complex, yet fresh and mouthwatering. Has this always been this sweet? It’s been a while since I tasted this, but that was a surprise, sugary rather than malty...finish is spicy and there is an acidity that lingers..not unpleasant, and overall, nice refreshing beer...that sweetness annoys tho!
Drank my first Hoegaarden today! I must say it was a pleasurable experience. It had a creamy texture, but still was refreshing. overall a beer worth trying.

Draft from San Diego Brewing Company.  Hazy pastel yellow.  Almost white.  Bright white head that left quickly.  Not much lacing either.  Aromas of lemon heads and vanilla.  Flavors were lemonheads again and some clove (or is THAT what coriander is?)  A pretty good beer.

The first wheat beer I ever tried, and still a favourite of mine, inspite of its expense in the UK (generally upwards of £3.20 a pint). The scent when you pour it is quite lemony, and indeed it can be drunk with a slice of lemon. The gentle colour and the blend of spices and aromas as you sink this make it so very drinkable. It is so very fruity, and pours with a very good head.

It looks like sparkling lemonade (and, in fact, it is often served with lemon), and smells spicy, almost gingery.  The healthy carbonation adds to the spiciness, which has a effervescent corriander edge to it.

Bottle: Pale yellow, typical nearly white color, hazy, huge fluffy white head, fairly attractive lacing. &nbsp Citrusy nose, not terribly strong, made up of corriander, orange peel, and wheat. &nbsp Pale corriander flavor on the tongue, very understaded. &nbsp Fairly full mouthfeel, wheaty, with a decent body. &nbsp Weakened flavor by the time of finish. &nbsp Needs to be a bit more spiced!

a mes rate:
ok we have all tried this one. it was what got me started and still holds a special place in my heart. i am not going to waste time talking about citrus and vanilla as you have all heard that before too. not what it was when i first tried it some years ago now. i am not going for all this frosted glass, slice of lime and herbs crap either. smacks a bit of interbrew these days but still hits the spot and if the pumps are looked after well still a good beer garden scoop for a sunny day

Cloudy light blonde in color.  Moderately aromatic, full of fruit and spice, giving a scent of curacao and coriander, along with a light hint of hay.  Flavor is light and airy, coating with a butter toffee blanket and loaded with light spice; coriander and curacao.  A pleasant, yet unexciting witbier.  Boy I wish I could have tried this 20 years ago.

Draught @ Papago
A funny thing happened to me the other night, I actually drank two glasses of Hefe Weizen and a Witbier all in one setting, not that they are bad, its just they are some of my least favorite sub-styles, even in the rapidly approaching Arizona summer. The beers I had were a Hacker-Pschorr, Weihenstephaner and the object of this review a Hoegaarden Wit.
The beer fresh from the tap is a beclouded yellowish-white with a monstrous white creamy head that lingers for a long time before dissipating, and the residual lace forms a tight screen to obfuscate the glass. Nose is spicy, hints of cloves and coriander, sweet malt and a slight citrus like tartness, start is lightly sweet with a mild grain presence and the top light in feel. Finish is stinging in its acidity with the hops light and pleasing, a real refreshing change of pace for this lover of strong Belgian Ales, very dry aftertaste finishes off this excellent beer, I wonder if my palate is changing once again?

(Bottle 25 cl) Very pale, almost milky white appearance. Lght in body but incredibly fresh and quenching with it’s perfect balance between the slightly sour notes from both the wheat and the orange peel and the perfumy coriander. On a hot summer’s day it’s hard to find a more refreshing beer. Seems to have lost a bit of character in recent years. 160793

(bottle) Hazy yellow colour with a small fizzy white head. Aroma of orange peel. Initially sparkling, high carbonated malty, yeasty taste with a smooth fruity aftertaste with some coriander spice and honey notes. Refreshing.
Pours cloudy yellow-white.  Citrusy yeasty aroma.  Flavor of citrus and coriander.  Pretty nice Witbier.
Bottle. Nice, fresh aroma with a touch of lemon. Classic witbier appearance. Solid flavor, again a bit of lemon. beatiful mouthfeel. Overall very recommendable.
A very tasty witbier, but not my favorite style.  Still a little boring.  I’m not a fan of beers that need fruit served with them to encourage flavor.
Tap: hazy, yeasty aroma and flavour. Nice white head, perfect on a hot sunny day with lemon.

Fine, fine Belgian.  Pours with a nice, frothy head and a yellow body.  The nose immediately give away hints of the yeast, citrus, and orange to come.  Palate is slippery, and the taste is almost just like the nose.  A bit sour in the finish.  Good stuff.
A nice refreashing wit. Nice cloudy yellowish colour. Great during the summer time.

Best Belgian White? C’mon....
It;s an OK beer but not more than that. Ordinary Witbier-taste, very refreshing but boring and even on the thin side. Completely uninteresting, I’ve had loads of Whites that were better.

On tap at The Standing Order in Derby on 11/03/05.

Cloudy pale yellow colour.

May look like dirty fizzy dish water, but quite a nice sharp refreshing taste.

Available in the small bottle served in the appropriate glassware at the Sharp Edge Creekhouse in Pittsburgh, PA.  Very light and bubbly, wheaty, with hints of lemon.  Then my brother noted that it tastes like a lemon dropped into alka-seltzer.  It ruined this beer for me.  Otherwise, I might have liked it.

Draft, Nice to find this served on tap just like any other beer. Yellow with a milky haze. Properly wit-like in taste, with a note of coriander. Of course there’s a lemon taste, since it was served with a slice of lemon. Refreshing, nice to sit and nurse as the evening wears on.
I actually like other Belgian Whites better, but this beer looks so cool! Refreshing with lots of wheaty taste.

Very pale and hazy; firm medium white head; fruity, very aromatic nose (citrus, orange, coriander); fizzy, sparkling, refreshing; very smooth; fruity and a bit sourish aftertaste. A summer-wine........
I don’t understand all the fuss about this beer. Thin, poor taste. I couldn’t even finish it. Maybe just not my style.

a sweet citrusy aroma coming off a cloudy yellow body with a foamy white head.  flavor is typically crisp and mildly sweet, with hints of orange and spices.  a very refreshing, quenching mouthfeel that would be good anytime.  a very enjoyable beer.
Poured nice white-gold color, citrus flavor, easy drinking beer, nice on the tongue. would happily drink again!

Tasted 03/04/2005.  330ml bottle from New Worl, Miramar.
Hazy, straw gold, almost watery.  Yeast in the glass look like flecks of gold from Shantytown.  Wow, never noticed that before!  The billowing, airy, white head quickly collapses into a nice thin head that laces strongly.  First hit on the nose is sulfurish but this quickly disapates and leaves the classic corainder and citrus (more lemony than orange to me).  Mouthfeel is very light and slightly tingly.  Slightly sour citrus flavour that shows through more sweet wheat as it warms.  At even warmer temperatures there is a hint of boiled candy on the nose.  Palate again tingly (the spice and citrus, I guess).

With a thin white head, cloudy appearance, and beautiful aroma this beer is one of my favorites.  The corriander and orange peel provides  the perfect balance of flavor to the beer.  Extra points for the oversized glass that makes you feel like a king while drinking it!

I had to re-rate this beer.  I had this on tap at a local pub. Beer was poured in one of the big Hoegaarden glasses.  Poured cloudy pale yellow with a nice head. Lots of wheat & yeast in the smell. The citrus in taste was very forward.  I have also had this from a bottle and they were lacking a little in the taste but still better that my first experence with this beer (mabey I got a bad batch the first time)

Falls somewhere around a 5/10 at best, maybe 4.5/10.  Hard-to-detect aroma, appearance a cloudy urine-yellow but nice head + retention.  Flavor fluffy and light without any pretense of depth.  Average mouthfeel.  Perhaps the lightest of light Belgians.  I’d be curious to see how this compares to 1 parts Belgian Strong mixed with 1 parts American macro.  Letsee, [4/5 + 0.5/5] / 2 = 2.25/5.  There you go.

Pours a light cloudy yellow.  Aroma is of wheat and some lemon.  Same in the flavor.  I guess if you’re a fan of this type of brew then it might be ok, but I personally find the taste of wheat unpleasant in my beer.  I bet that if I drank this type of beer more then  I’d get used to it. Also, it’s too expensive.  At least in Arkansas it is.

The first time I had this beer I thought it tasted like vaseline and my friend said it reminded him of balogna. People keep telling me to try it again, but I just don’t seem able after my frist impression. rating it a bit higher because I seem to be missing something.

Poured a cloudy light yellow color with a medium bright white head... The aroma was of belgian yeast with a hint of lemon.  The flavor was lemon and wheat with a small hint of the belgian yeast.  This was very refreshing and would be a great beer to have around the pool on a hot summer day but was not great.  I could find a better session for less money..

Yellow straw hazy hue, with thick foamy head, leaving laces on the side of the glass. Fresh wheat, citric fruits of lemons, grapefruits,oranges aromas with a spicy touch of coriander, follows through a medium-bodied with a mellowness palate, a lactic accent coming from the acidity of his citrus flavors leading by the orange dry peels, who gives it his quenching taste.
good looking when poured and likes a little lemon added to it..... refreshing and ver drinkable
I was unimpressed with this beer.  I had it in bottle, but I followed th puring directions on the label.  It was hard to drink, too sour.  I think Paulaner Hefe is a much better beer.

The first time I had this beer it tasted like balogna. However at the insistence of a trusted friend I gave this beer another try. Wow definately better the second time around while still not my favorite the pale straw color along with the citrus/orange peel aroma with a hint of coriander was definately more appealing. The taste this time was spicier showing some pepper along with a champagne like carbonation.

Interesting beer!  A friend was surprised that I had never sampled this one and suggested it.  It pours a nice big head with a cloudy pale yellow colour.  Very attractive beer!  The aroma is sweet and fruity, some hops detectable, but mostly a light citris smell.  Goes down very smooth, with nice palate depth.  Maybe too much carbonation, but doesn’t take away from the beer.  Head diminishes rapidly and leaves you with a smooth spicy beer which would be great on a hot day.

Haze pale yellow, thick white, creamy, rounded head. Spicy nose with a touch of citrus. Spicy fresh flavour with segments of orange, lemon and wheat.
Light bodied with low bitterness.
has the nice citrus and floral aroma and flavor of lots of gelgian whites.  this was bottled and had little lacing but a lasting head.   very hazy golden- attractive.

12 oz bottle with use by date 3/23/06
poured with nice white head
very smooth and refreshing, classic belgian white ale
very drinkable, excellent example of this type beer
one of my favorite types of beer, and one of the finest beers I’ve had recently, highly recommended
Sweet floral malt aroma. Cloudy yellow colour with fair head. Sweet malt flavour. Light easy drinking beer. Fizzy palate.

For a wit beer, it doesn’t get much better than this, considering the availability, and it actually tastes pretty good.  Poursa hazy hue with a nice white head, aromas of wheat, a hint of spice.   Flavors of the same with a mild bitterness and that mighty orange peel tinge.
The pour is pale yellow, almost lemonade looking, with light, white foam. Wheaty, sweet aroma. Crisp citrus flavor. Very lite and smooth. Im not a big fan of wheat beers, but this is very refreshing.
Draft. Poured a Milky amber with a medium white head that lasted. Aroma was a sweet with a citrus tone. Flavor was refreshing and light with a short finish. Drinkable as a brew lemonade.

Hazy, pale golden color, small white head.  Aroma of lemon, pepper, with maybe some cloves.  Flavor is light and refreshing, with some lemon enhanced by a light spiciness.  Less spicy than many whites, making this a nice brew for a hot day.
foggy pale color. very slight citrus aroma .Very crisp ,finishes with a mild citrus flavor . faint aftertaste, a good refreshing  brew for summer .

Very nice, cloudy, darksh yellow color with a medium white head of very fine bubbles.  Fruity (banana?) aroma and flavor.  Mildly spicy taste.  Medium to light body.  Fizzy texture.  With an ever-so-slightly metallic finish.
Very drinkable, to say the least.  I found this similar to a Weihenstaphaner, but not quite as spicy.  Teriffic white, foamy head, plenty of carbonation, slight fruitiness, very good.

So this is the #1 rated White? I don’t get it. Has hardly any aroma. Appearance makes up for it though. Crisp light & refreshing. Light spices & yeasty flavors. Palate seems to be thin. I prefer Allagsh White and Celis White when it was brewed in Austin over this one. Both have far more flavor.
Pours with a nice head that dissipates rather quickly.  A slightly sour aroma, but hardly offensive.  A nice taste, nothing that I can discern, but overall, very good.

This is a very drinkable Belgian White which effectively uses coriander and orange to engineer a beer suited for the masses who want something good but not too overwhelming or complex. It does seem to have a more complex taste than American-made witbiers like Blue Moon and Allagash White. It is definately sweeter than the latter. This is hazy in the glass as most of these beers and some like it better on tap with a fruit slice, I actually prefer it in a bottle.

We all know the look.  Floral aroma with smattering of lemon zest. Flavors include white cardamom sprinkled over a Twizzler-tangerine-limeade soda smoothie.  Crisp mouthfeel--I acknowledge that this is preferable as a summer brew, not a St. Paddy’s, but I’d rated all the other taps recently.  A tasty treat, but not for everyone.

Nice opaque yellow with bright white head. Light mouthfeel makes this refreshing in the proper climate. Not as over-the-top spicy as some domestic wit examples. Like the description says: Well calibrated sweet and sour (well, spiciness of orange peel and coriander).

hazy light yellow pour with a small amount of white head. aroma is yeasty, sweet and spicy (cloves/anise?) . taste is the same plus a little bit of lemony citrus at the end.  nice refreshing mouthfeel.

Beautifully cloudy, pale yellow.  Smells yeasty, and of bananas and vanilla.  Tastes of cloves, honey, bananas and vanilla.  Sweet and peppery with notes of coriander, with subtle spiciness I’ll attribute to cloves.  Effervescent.  Creamy, milky finish.  Great beer.
i like how this beer looks in a glass.  it’s a very pleasant drink in hot summer days.

I swore off Belgian whites after trying Blue Moon years ago.  Finally tried Blue Moon again and loved it.  Wanted to try the real deal.  Personally I like Blue Moon better but this is starting to grow on me.  Color is a cloudy yellow, much lighter as mentioned before then Blue Moon.   Aroma of yeast and wheat.  No lacing and a decent diminishing head.  I personally think there is too much coriander taste to it.  It’s what hits you first and then as it passes along your tongue you finally get the citrus taste that Blue Moon gives you right away.  It’s not a bad beer but I personally like Blue Moon better as it’s tastier.
Tasted this one at fitzgeralds harp and bard. Poured yellow and cloudy, (yeast).  White head. Aroma of yeast  and fruit. This was pleasant. Not my favorite style, but good.

Bottle.  My favourite beer.  Pours a pale, cloudy yellow colour.  Hints of orange and spice are found in the aroma.  The flavour is delicious with distinctive citrus and spice elements and a beautiful light bitterness.  Reward yourself and try this beer.
spicy, citrus aroma.  cloudy with solids floating throughout.  amazing flavor...full of spices and citrus.  one of my favorite beers.

Draft ! I had this after the blue moon white(BMW)
A pale yellow milky beer it was lighter than BMW the white head was moussy with a few choice peaks. The aroma was spices vanilla,nutmeg and some faint citrus.It tasted yeasty and wheaty
the citrus is subdued but the coriander spiciness blends well.Some sweetness
but its thin body and lively carbonation
rounded all the edges.Very Drinkable and better than BMW but it was twice the price.
truely a great beer!! cloudy, crisp, and awesome example of a wit beer.  Spicey start -- citrus finish.  the standard of beligan whites!!

Tap at Café Amsterdam (Copenhagen). Served in big-ass Hoegaarden glass. Cloudy, pale yellow. Nice head. A pretty beer. Aroma and flavor are both very friendly and harmonious; fresh coriander and citrus, some yeast. Supremely drinkable.

Bouteille de 330 ml. Arôme: Odeur d’agrumes et d’anis. Apparence: Couleur paille pâle opaque. Moyen col mousseux qui perdure. Faible carbonisation. Fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût d’agrumes et d’épices. Durée de l’arrière goût moyenne. Palette: Corps et texture mince. Carbonisation moyenne. Arrière goût de citron. (Rating #93)
A soft yellow tone with frothy white head. very tasty, very sweet. a quality belgian white

Claudy cool-yellow beer with an airy creamy white foam. Citrus and banana in the nose, also faint hints of coriander and curacao orangepeel. Touche of dough and yeast in the nose. Light clean taste with touche of wheat and lemon candy. afthertaste is clean, refreshing and a litle too watery.

Tasted this one years back, but it seems to have been ’mass market’ modernised now, as it didn’t appear to be the same as it once was!. Tasted from the bottle and poured into its own stumpy tumbler. Pours an opaque pale ’wheat’ yellow, with a short dense and creamy head. Aromas of spicy coriander, fell second to a candy sugar sweetness that was cloying prior to even the first sip. In the mouth, a smooth, lightly carbonated, pasty and yeasty palate revealed light citric zest and candy sugar sweetness, cloying and gluggy, with no lactic yeast and wheat hit or spicy balance. Still, all else aside, it is oddly sessionable, though cloyingly sweet and not what I remember it as....
My first taste of Witbier, a very good introduction indeed. A must try, must drink. Cloudy pour, spicy, fruity. Good.
a decent white beer.  flavors included anis and cinnamon spice with a hint of citrus.

One of my last "accessible" beers to be rated.  Poured a murky white (with the yeast) with a tall fizzy white head.  Aroma is light citrusy spice.  Taste is very well-rounded mild spiciness with sublte fruit undertones.  The flavor seemed somewhat less profound than Allagash White, but this beer gets extra points for pure drinkability.  Consumed at slightly above refrigerator temperature, it is thirst-quenching and quite satisfying.  It’s simply sweet and subtle character makes it an excellent companion to simpler salty richer foods.  I drank it alongside a chicken parmigiana dinner and the pairing was near perfect.

Hoegaarden pours a sickly clouded yellow colour, lightly carbonated appearance witha  minimal brilliant white head. The nose holds the quintessential notes of orange peel and coriander with some citrus anda  light spicing beneath, which threaten further interest beyond the standard whitbeer , but provide nothing but a slight metallic edge. Tastes mirror the aromas found originally but also provides light spicing in the refreshing whitbeer finish, the only part of this beer which really proves itself.
A very standard whitbier although it is refreshing , if you have a penchant for this type of beer drink it cool in the summer.

draft. I had this about a month ago in NYC and absolutly loved it. Probably the best witbier i’ve had to this point.  A cloudy yellowish orange pour with a medium white head. Very fruity and citrusy in smell. Also a grassy wheat like smell and very dry on the finish. great beer.

Aroma:Orange,citrus,fruity,spices,wheat.   
Appearance:Hazy withe gold,small head.   
Gout:Orange,citrus,wheat.
Hint of citrus...mild brew better suited for Summer drinking.  Had it at  Ned Devines in Milton, Ont.  Quality beer overall, goes down real-smooth!!

Bottle, at No. 5.
Light yellow, unfiltered. Aroma and flavor of coriander and orange. Very fine.
Crisp, refreshing taste, but distinctly alcoholic.  Very nice balance of citrus and chocolate tastes.  A pleasant beer to be enjoyed on a summer afternoon.
Cloudy yellow pour, with a diminishing head.  Mild sweetness up to the finish.  Could be stronger.

Oh my god...this is what it’s all about.  Hard to express how unbelievably easily this beer goes down.  Little to no aftertase...period.  Cloudy body because of its unfiltered state adds to the intrigue.  They say, per capita, Belgium is the world’s most unique and varied producer...with a beer like this, it’s not hard to see why.  Do try this one.

Hazey yellow colour with a cotton white head. Yeast aroma with hints of orange and lemon. Taste is citrus’y and well blended into a smooth,un-sour, feeling. Sweet with a faint barley taste. very smooth and relaxing.

The classic wit. Orange and lemony aroma with hints of yeast smells.  Pours out a pale yellow with a huge white head that lasts.  Slightest sourness balances the sweet orangey flavors.  A great summer quaffer.

A fellow rate beerean gave me this beer in Mexico, and it became one of my favorite beers ever since.  Nice yellow/cloudy appearance with a creamy head.  Sweet and citric at just the right balance.  If you have not tried it, please do so!
Bottled. Yellow cloudy, big white head. Citric aroma with notes of yeast and wheat. Citric sweet barley in taste. Sweet aftertaste.
Not a bad white beer. Hints of citrus ride out the mouthful. Very drinkable.
Pours a very cloudy yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma is of fruit, namely oranges and lemons. Sweet flavor that is highlighted by the aforementioned fruit. A favorite during warm weather months.

One of the world’s great beers. Seeing this slowly becoming more available in Australia as demand grows shows there’s hope for us yet. Perhaps some of us will live long enough to see the State of Origin sponsored by this, rather  then the usual carbonated swill. It poured a cloudy unfiltered yellow with a prodigous lacing head. The rich yeasty nose promises citrus courtesy of the orange peel but I have never been able to pick the coriander. The medium-bodied palate feels full and creamy on the tongue. There are hints of orange in the tangy body, alongside the expected wheat characters. Effortless drinking. (Bottle)

12oz bottle. 51°. NB worthy glass.  Pours hazy yellow with a white head which started at about 3/4 inch and died down after a minute or so.  Smells wheaty with a touch of citrus.  Taste is a typical wheat beer with some spice and lemony citrus. Nice "full" mouthfeel.  The finish is light with some residual wheat flavor and a touch of tangy spice. A good wheat beer, but the flavors seemed muted.
Nice, but it is a little bit light, for my taste, for being a white beer, although it is a good beer.
Cloudy yellow colour (reminds a lemonade), with nice white head. Very sweet, I think. Good aroma with citrus notes. It’s a very refreshing beer, excellent for summer time.
Meget lys øl, en anelse uklar. Flot hvidt skum. Meget karakteristisk duft af appelsin. Den krydrede smag af koriander er gennemtrængende. Desuden citrusnoter og (naturligvis) gær. Rigtig god witbier!

Bottle.  Poured cloudy yellow straw color with white head.  Sugary, yeast, spice and coriander aroma.  Taste of wheat malt, coriander, spice and cereal. Very nice wheat beer.  

Biere de couleur jaune paille trouble avec un bon collet blanc.  Odeur sucre, levure, epices et coriandre.  Au gout, au remarque tout de suite le gout de ble, ensuite la coriandre, les epices et les cereales.  Tres bonne biere de ble

330ml brown bottle, tasted in Hoegaarden tumbler. Poured cloudy pale/lemon yellow. Nice creamy white head, effervescent body. Clove-like aromas, with some citrus and woody notes (sawdust). Sweet and orangy in the mouth, light yeast and wheat aftertaste.

One of the first "good" beers I ever had. And while not as impressive as it once seemed, this is still abig step up from industrial lagers. Pours a hazy pale yellow colour with an orangey nose. The flavour seems a little weak but still an enjoyable mix of citrus and spice. Could use some yeastiness to round it out.

Poured a cloudy popcorn color with a nice fluffy head. As per instuctionsi I swirled and poured the remaining sediment from the bottom of the bottle into my glass. The aroma was strong with wheat malt, citrus notes and banana. The taste was big and clean. Wheat flavor was upfront with a subtle bitterness following close. Light citrus/lemon notes come next. The aftertaste was yeasty and sweet like tapioka. A very refreshing wit. Highly recomended.

Cloudy, very pale straw-coloured beer with a good frothy white head. Very nice lacing and doesn’t overdo the carbonation. I was a bit worried to try this one after reading some of the descriptions since I normally don’t like overly spiced beers – (How many of you ratebeerians really go in the kitchen often enough to know what coriander smells like?) – but the citrus and spice isn’t overplayed at all. Very soft mouth feel and nice tangy aftertaste. Overall it certainly refreshes but it does lack enough character to really be one of the greats.

Bottled. 750 ml. Cloudy, pale yellow colour. Huge frothy head.  Lemony, coriander aroma, yeasty with something like lactic acid. Citric, spicy, slightly tart with, again, strong notes of coriander and lemon. A nice mouthfeel, goes down easily. But if this is, supposedly, the best this style has to offer, I don´t know what´s the point of it. The dominating aromas and flavours are added to the beer. Good hefeweizens have much more character than this and if you substract the artifcially added flavours from wit you are left with a yeasty, bland sub-par weizen.
Great beer.... definetlley one of my favorites. Great taste, color, and flavor!

250 mL bottle from Switzerland.  Really hazy  pale yellow Wit with thick creamy lacing white head.  Nice lemon and light spices in aroma.  Lemon comes out too in mouth, with  fresh wheat and coriander notes. This is so  classic! I like the 250 mL format. a good dieter’s portion...hehehe

A very good Belgian witbier. It was bit more "subtle," or perhaps more dulled than expected but it was still a lovely beverage. Nice spicy smell, with a fruity and citric flavor to it. The corriander seems to play a big part in the flavor. Beautiful to look at, with a pale cloudy yellow color and creamy head.

On tap @Papago. Finally back in Arizona.  Pours a nice cloudy light yellowish, almost grainy, color.  Light sweet orange citrus aroma. Mellow in the flavor but nicely balanced, very thirst quenching. Has some wheat notes but not overbearing. It’s one of those beers that dont wow you but you cant put it down.

I’m happy with this beer.  I don’t normally like fruity flavors but the whole package just sits well with me.  Nothing stands out on it’’s own here.  Everything is balanced and combind to produce a very good beer.  I like this a bit on the cold side.  I have nothing negative to say about this beer.  It’s not my first choice but it certainly will quench your thirst.

I never have Hoegaarden by the bottle, but it’s one of the Belgian trio on tap at my local, so I have it several times a week. This could dull the novelty of it, and perhaps it does, but I still enjoy it immensely. It has a wonderfully cloudy appearance, that is complimented by the citrusy, herbal flavour that is so incredibly quenching and refreshing. For a major, mass-produced beer, this is outstanding.

Finally, I get around to trying the classic. Pours a cloudy gold with a medium sized white head. The aroma is the expected lemon peels and corriander. The taste is a nice lemon and orange. The finish is fairly bready. Slightly sour and this adds to the interesting character. A great wit, but not the best.

Okay for its style. If you let it linger in the mouth for a minute it shows some successful orange and lemony citrus blended in. Also, the aftertaste is largely citrus and not very "wheaty". In general I don’t like wheat beers but this is ok.

What t say, it destroys the competition. This is definetly the best in its class!

The first , the best , the only choice!!!

Well I found this in January in one of my favorite bars, and I thought, why are you serving this now?  It’s bound to be a llittle subdued.  I belive all wits should be drunk at their peak, before the spices and citrus have time to decompose.  It’s the most available, but not the best.
The ubiquitous witbier. Standard fare, not spectacular but extremely drinkable - a good summer beer.

Tasted in France - bottled. Pours a very opaque and pale yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of grapefruit, pinneaple, apricots, chalk and dust. Smooth yet crisp and refreshing. The flavour is quite mild but it leaves a very distinct citrus aftertaste. Very enjoyable level of carbonation and nice lacing. Delightful to drink.

Bottle: soft aroma, not much to it. somewhat fruity. very unique looking. hazy yellow/white colour. very thin head that doesnt last. tastes like very mild orange. malty aftertaste. slightly carbonated, just right.

Hazy pale yellow with a fluffy thick white head and nice lacing.  Yeasty citrus aroma.  Sweet with spice and citrus flavors. Very light and lively with carbonation in the mouth, but it doesnt seem thin at all.  Possibly the lightest and most refreshing beer I have ever had.  Very smooth and easy drinking.  Excellent in every respect, even the price!

Why am I rating a summer beer in the middle of the winter?  Hoegaarden white is the beer that peaked my interest in Belgian Style Ales.  This white beer is the beer is used as my standard for a long time.  Rich in orange, coriander and vanilla, pours with a full white foamy head.  Best enjoyed on a hot summer day.

Hazy straw with a fluffy and yeasty off-white head and medium lacing.  Citrus and malty aroma with plenty of yeast and maybe a touch of herbs.  Very refreshing flavor with crisp citrus notes and vanilla smoothness.  Malts all over the place in the flavor and finish.  Not as interesting as most of the artisinal Belgian ales but surely a good choice if you’re looking for a classic Witbier.
Fizzy head that quickly recedes. Aroma is spicy and yeasty, a ton of orange peel in the flavor.

The aroma is spicy and fruity with wheat and a hint of flowers. Smooth and not too bitter with a hint of citrus. This is a wheat lovers beer. Many other beers that are not bitter are also weak or watery but not this beer.
This is one of the most refreshing beers you can get. It’s hazy (unfiltered)with hints of coriander and citrus. Is a cheap good brew.

This beer is extrodinary. I have never had any thing quites like it. Very well balanced. Pours very pale and cloudy, with a thick white head that thins slowly. The aroma is pleasant, that of apples. It kind of reminds me of the smell of a cider. The flavor is delightful as well. Apples, citrus and spices are present. The spicy sweetness lingers in your mouth. This beer is very smooth and drinkable.  This beer would be good all year round. It is refreshing enough to be enjoyed during the summer, but spicy enough to remind you of the holidays. Very good, Very delicious, try it!

This was a Christmas present.  The head formed easily but dissapated. there was lacing down the glass. The color was a cloudy straw.  The taste was  yeasty with a hint of spice.  It was not my type of beer.  I like more hops.  I rescored this wheat beer o March 9, 2008.  It is too sweet with nohops.  the orange flavors are just not me.
Bottle.  Pours a unique hazy light gold with thick bone-white head.  Aroma is of hops, spices and bread.  Taste is yeasty, very spicy and somewhat citrusy.  Very tasty.  Excellent beer.

Hazy very pale yellow beer with a short lasting head but persistent lacing. Very interesting aromas of fruit and spices, much brighter and fresher than most wheat beers. Spices and citrus flavors with a lingering sweetness. Thin mouthfeel with ample carbonation and extreme drinkability. Makes me want warm summer night.

The aroma from this brew is heavenly.  Fruity with orange and coriander flavors.  It is a thin beer which makes it exceptionally good for a hot summer night.  Not  even a hint of bitterness makes it all to easy to drink far to many of these.
Hazy yellow in color with a creamy head. Aroma is orange and spicyness. Flavor is slightly sweet, yeast, spice. Finish is warming

[From a botle] Fizzy, cloudy yellow with a thick foamy head that diminishes to a film, leaving behind white lace.  Fruity and spicy aroma iwth cloves, orange, banana, lemon, and a touch of malt.  Flavour reflects aroma with a little more lemon and much more obvious malt.  No bitterness.  Feels and tastes very clean.  Explosive carbonation.  Just a little thin for my taste.
Orange sweet and fruity tasting.  Pale in colour.  Very lilttle bitterness and easy drinking.  Alot of character compared to the stuff I usually drink (macro).  Quite enjoyable

Nice frothy head but not very stable, light yellow color, hazy. Mandariny citrusy aroma with notes of coriander. Flavor is moderately sweet, taste of sugared mandarin juice, light bodied, refreshing. Coriander and a light astringent dryness in the finish. Pleasant, very pleasant.

I’ve been eyeballing this brew for a few weeks at the grocery now, so I picked up a sixer of it last night. Glad I did - It was about as I expected it to be. Basically, it is a much better Blue Moon. Pours a decent golden color with a peculiar haze, which definitely fits their claim of being unfiltered. The head is a nice yellowish white creamy pillow. It didn’t last too long though - not sure if it was how I poured it or if it does this anyway. You can definitely smell the citrus in this stuff. The taste is very light orange w/ spice, a refreshing change from the overly fruity Blue Moon. Goes down smooth and leaves no funky aftertastes. Honestly, the only negative part of this brew is the cost. I guess if I am going to spend $8.49 for a sixer, I grab Anchor Steam Beer instead. Definitely a nice change of pace though. Highly recommended if you are hankering for a slightly sweet brew.

Draught.  Elephant & Castle Pub in Grove City, PA.  I had a hell of a time finding this one on the site.  Forgot that there were two "a’s" in Hoegaarden.  Poured extremely light colored and very hazy with a small but sturdy head that laced the glass well.  Nice aroma of sour hay and citrus lemon that mixed quite well.  My wife looked away from the bar and it was gone.  Easy quaffing beer that seems to mix things together very well.  Some spices in the nose (must be coriander and orange peel) and those flavors come through in a nice light way.  Although this beer has very little body, it seems to fit the taste.  Although I am an admitted hophead, I really do enjoy a good Belgian Witbier as well.  Nicely done.

This is a beer that taste good.  You could give it to a child and they probably would like it.  Normally I’m into bitter nasty beer that gives me the false impression that I’m manly...but this stuff is just so pleasant.  It gos down incredibly smooth, the scent is pleasing, and the after taste is mild.  A very unique flavor(well...except for blue moon which rips this beer off).  If you’re drinking with a chick who normally doesn’t like beer....have her try this.

Pours very pale with a huge head.  Decent aroma of coriander and orange peel.  Flavor starts off good, but ends watery--after it’s gone you don’t know it was there at all.  Not bad, not special.

Rerate: better than before. Still ends watery, but there is an aftertaste. And the drinkability can’t be beat.

interesty hazy lemony look--looks like carbonated lemon juice.  light mild aroma, citrus and sugar.  flavor is very neutral with a superbly drinkable mouthfeel--practically drinks itself.  the best wit i’ve had.
Didn’t find this anything that special, easy-drinking with a hint of fruit, but overall didn’t seem that exciting and I feel it may be a touch over-rated.
Pours thin yellow with no head. Aroma is weak. Taste is orange, soapy and watery. Belgian whites are gross. I am sorry to say, but they are. No hop flavor at all. Gross tart aftertaste.
Frothy and bubbly blonde in the glass. Not alot of character here. Very standard tasting beer. I still haven’t found a white I really like.
Clear, yellow straw-like. Foam of good duration. Veiled and elegant aspect.
Hazy blonde appearance, decent enough flavor, but I found it lacking, when compared to other fine witbiers I have had.  Very pleasant Aroma, fruity wheat.  Overall, good, but not great.

Pretty opaque light color. I find this beer less carbonated on tap (which I like better).  Slight citric taste makes this a great Summer session beer. One of the better beers that is available at your average liquor store.
Was not impressed by this beer at all.  Poured a thick white head and had a cloudy appearance to it.  Flavor-wise I didn’t like it.  There just wasn’t much there for me.
Light color. Pleasant Orange aroma. Has a sweet and sour taste with a slightly hoppy feel. finishes clean.
This beer tastes like lemonade to me.  That is all I am going to say about that.  Will try again and re-rate.

This is a very smooth and refreshing belgian white, but I still like Blue Moon a lot better because it has more flavor, I tasted no orange in the Hoegaarden but did get slight banana as it warmed up. Not a bad beer but if it’s sitting next to Blue Moon I’m picking up the Blue Moon.
fruity and spicy.  smooth and refreshing with a dry finish.  yeasty aroma and taste with some clove.

Pronounced WHO-GAR-DEN, This is a great beer that alot misunderstand. First I DONT DRINK THIS BEER, I hate belgium beers, HOWEVER it’s my wife’s fav! 
On to the review, It’s a cloudy almost white golden wheat beer, herbs on the nose, thick white head. palate of silk. Smoth taste, just a hint of hop, mild sweet with a domonat flavour of roses. Herbal aftertaste, Cilantro and just a hit of zest. second aftertaste clean, like a american dry. Leaves a lovley white foam on on walls of you’re glass, jst like a good beer ALWAYS should. SPECIAL ATTRIBUTE: feels soooooo good in the tummy. Calming slowly roaling gentle tide. Exelent soother to... umm ...when a girl... ummm, well you know... once a month for 5-7 days...  Now on to HOW to drink it. First, if you have it in the pub, a lemmon wege will be sitting on the rim. DONT PUT THIS IN THE BEER. the acid completly cancles the flavours. WASH THE RIM WITH THE LEMMON BEFORE EACH PULL ON YOU’RE PINT!!!!!  it’ll add the perfect amount of lemmon to every mouthfull. If you ask for a WHO-GAR-DEN and they correct you with HOH-GAARDEN, tell them that you were right in the first place, and belgiuns are actualy offended by the false name. IF YOU HAVE THIS AT HOME. first, ignore the bottle instructions. Take a chilled bottle, and SLOWLY rotate it upside down. Hold it for 20 seconds, roll it back strait, another 20 seconds. Repeet. Rince a 12 oz glass, If you’ve got a Hoegarden Glass, use it, if not  a strait Pillsner glass is better than a goblet.  Rince the glass with cold water, shake it so there are small sparce drops of water all through-out. open beer. Wait 5 seconds. pour 3/4 of the beer at a 45 degree angle. Let beer rest 50-60 seconds while you SWIRL the remaining beer to dissolve all leftover lees. with the glass on the table, pour the remaning beer strait in the center of the head. Try to get every drop of foam from the bottle. Wait another 10 seconds. Use a knife or you’re finger to "cut" from one side of the glass head to the other, smothing the head flat with the glass and removing all head above the rim. 1/8 a lemon on the rim. And you’re done. Exelent beer for a lady, plus if you go through all trouble to pour you’re lady a beer, it shows care. Cheers!

A very tasty and very dependable Belgian White. The subtle taste of spices add to this wheat style. Not overpowering but refreshingly different than American Lagers. Leave out the lemon, it just screws up the taste.
Wow, a Belgian I actually like a lot!  Pretty smooth and subtle tasting, the flavoring was right on the money and satisfying to the last drop.  Thoroughly enjoyed, cheers Rob!
Asked for something light and different, was given this brew.  On tap, slice of orange.  Very fruity, light, refreshing, bit of a tang.

For a lot of people, this as just as easy to get as that ’other’ Belgian White, the one with the moon on the bottle. I enjoy the citrus flavor and the color, matched by it’s drinkability, a common and great tasting White.
Bottled. Hazy straw, fluffy white head, yeast, citrus, hint of coriander, hint of clove; heaven. Slice of lemon? Slice of lime? Whatever! Absolute favourite summer drink.

(bottle) Recommended to me because I asked for something with a lighter taste.  A cloudy yellow color that looked to me like a cross between a wheat and a lager - neither of which I care for.  The taste was actually pretty decent though.  The bartender was telling me about all of these different flavor components but I didn’t really get any of them.  Just a fairly plain, safe beer.

On tap at The Wlatzing Weasel London Ontario:  Pale straw coloured body with medium sized white foamy head.  Yeasty, citrusy Aromas.  Tastes of yeast and spice (possibly nutmeg).  Spice lingers in mouth, very smooth beer.  Very Tasty!
I like this beer for the value. A crisp, refreshing flavor, good for lunch. It reminds me of soda, only better.

Really wasn’t overly impressed for all the hype.  Poured a cloudy off-white/yellow, almost green in color.  Aroma of citrus and orange.  Went down very smooth, but taste was overly citrus for my liking.  Still, not a bad beer, just not to my tastes.

I’ve been enjoying witbiers since I’ve been aware of their existence, and yet this is my first time sampling "the original".Color: a cloudy, almost opaque pale yellow/bright white. Head: thick, lacey, white, fluffy as a cloud, slowly tumbling down. Aroma: uplifting, light and lovely! Full of citrus, spice, lemon/orange...wide open, spacious, airy, friendly and hospitable. All that in an aroma? Yes, Indeed!
A great big barrage of hops charges the palate at first, along with the gritty, grainy wheat texture. After that attack, very smooth and mellow. Light in body,and feeling, but rich in flavor, character, and soul. An utter delight every time it touches the tongue! An overall honey flavor dominates the remainder of the drink, and the delicious hops, the texture, the spice, continue to dance on the palate and provide for a richly rewarding refreshment. 
When other folks talk of "nothing beating a Bud Light/Corona/generic yellowy water" on a hot summer’s day, they would be wiser to wrap their lips around a glass of Hoegaarden. Wiser, happier, more improved in all aspects as a human being!
What a beautiful beer!

Decent head for a witbier.  Not much of an aroma, but there’s hints of spice and citrus.  Spicy, fruity, citrusy.  Very refreshing.  It’s the perfect summer beer.  This is the standard by which all Belgian Whites should be measured

Not much head, unclear pale yellow colour, but it is full of spices and fruits. Fizzy, really reminds of Champagne. It’s taste is very complex and evokes lots of interesting ingredients. This is really the Queen of white beers !
Excellent white bier: refreshing, fruity, spicy, slightly acidic, very good.

I first had this beer on tap and really enjoyed it.  I then found it in bottles and it is now one of the beers I like to drink.   I use to enjoy Blue Moon but since I have had this I don’t know if I can go back.  A light refreshing enjoyable beer.
(tap) tastey! beautifully light and delicate in color... even from the sampling i had i knew i’d be ordering this one again. apple, pear and citrus notes

Oh the classic belgian white beer.  Normal hazy oragne color, white soapy head, and of course the citrusy aroma and flavors.  I am of course not a huge fan of the belgian white, or at least I have not yet found one that I like.

Delicious wit.  Pours a cloudy yellow color with a serious white head.  Sweet citric aroma, some spicing.  Good, full mouthfeel.  Citric flavors with apple, pear, and spices.  Bit of an orange-ish aftertaste.  Refreshing, excellent brew.

Probably the best wheat beer I ever tasted, it leaves you with incredible flavour in your mouth, could really taste a bit of orange in it, if you are ever in Belgium thats the beer to drink, fantastic
I have been a fan of Hoegaarden for a good while now, and this is one of my favorites from them. Nice and fresh citrus flavor, this beer is extremely refreshing. Great beer for a nice summer day.

A few smooth and satisfying beer. I had this for ther first time on tap at a local watering hole and was blown away. An EXCELLENT witbier. IF you want a more descriptive review, i have to say read tsarman’s review its classic.  The best part about this beer is its ubiquity. It seems to be popping up everywhere, and this is a good thing, because it offers a decent alternative to the other piddle that is being served in gin mills across this country. SIt back, relax and let this smooth brew light your fire (smoothly).

This is a pretty different beer… 

When you get the over-sized tumbler glass (especially designed for Hoegaarden) it looks like you just got a glass of over carbonated, fresh squeezed apple juice: A cloudy white-yellow liquid with white, half-thick, long-lasting foam.

Then you smell the beer and discover a mix of sweet lemonade, apples, ladies perfume, paperhanger’s paste and soft soap.

The taste is enormously fresh and the carbon dioxide sparkles in your mouth like it is going to explode, but then it just fades away leaving lots of tastes to explore: Sour apples, bitter almonds, hints of leather and white bread. 

The aftertaste is as complex and unexpected as the smell and taste: A taste of caraway and other spices used in dark bread is followed by a fresh and refreshing flavour of sour fruit-drops and almonds. 

Not like any other beer that I have came across, not even other white beer comes close. A break when you don’t want to have just another beer, and my first choice when I want to be refreshed a hot summer night. 

I think that all people with even a slight interested in beer should at least try a Hoegaarden once.

12 oz bottle: Pours a cloudy yellow with a thick white head. Aroma is that of a weissbier; fairly sharp with a hint of citrus. First taste is very different than I expected. Full of flavor, fairly spicy with a hint of orange. Not quite sure how much I like this one, but it grows on you the more you taste it.

Very enjoyable and light.  This is such a different beer.  Citricy and Spicy, very lemony and served with lemon slice.  The beverage is lemony yellow with a little white head.  My first one seemed watery but my second packed lots of flavor.  I look forward to having more.

(Draft) This beer grows on you. With it’s cloudy appearance and yeast laden chunkyness it’s a bit of a strech for someone who is new to this style. If you can get past that you will find a delicate lemony flavor that packs some nice spicyness. Full of flavor and great on a hot summer day with a wedge of lemmon and a stamper.

One of my favorite beers.  Found it in NYC be accident and had to wait years before it arrived in Ohio.  I like Bell’s Winter Wheat better but I can get this beer in the summer.  Very refreshing with a clean taste.  A great light beer for any occasion w/ enough flavor to go with food from wings to lighter fare.
Watery flavor, too citrus-heavy (especially toward lemon scent), but it smells and looks nice.  There are much better witbiers out there, such as Blanche de Brugges (sp?).

Very pale lemon in colour, a little cloudy. Spicey nose with excellent lift. VG palate feel, quite a full bodied style but not alcohol heavy.  More spice and some medicinal notes.  In my opinion the benchmark witbier in OZ for $3-$4.

Bizarre glowing yellow color that looked awesome. The smell caught me way off guard, made me wonder what was up with the style. Yeasty and peppery sort of smell with some very faint fruitiness, almost smelled like musty dust. The mouth is where it’s at. Silky, smooth. Some bubblegum highlights in the taste, as well as the coriander. Some hidden cloves and citrus as well as the usually banana. All in all, superb.

Bottle:  Hazy very light yellow w/ ghostly white highlights around the edges.  Coriander and orange abound in the aroma, but they’re light.  Predominant, but not overwhelming.  Wheat malt is right behind as is a hint of clovey spice.  Flavor is well balanced, tart in the finish & aftertaste, and spicy citrus between.  Spicy yeast and a light acidic sourness from start to finish.  Light bodied, highly carbonated, and lightly acidic in the m/f.  This is a very enjoyable Wit!  I know it’s the stereotypical "Wit" but I’ve had much better in the aroma from Vuuve, but flavor is solid and refreshing.

I was attracted to this beer by its novelty and have come to savor its broad palate of flavors.  A fun one to drink, very fruity.  It’s not as great from a bottle, but if you can get it on tap in one of the round chalice-like glasses, it’s worth any extra cost.

Bottle. Grapefruit juice colour, nice white head. Quite spicey (lots of coriander), with almost no trace of orange (maybe felt it once), suprisingly refreshing.  It’s overall, quite an enjoyable white.
Bottle.  Fruity and yeasty.  Cloudy yellow body.  Enjoyable, but not remarkable.
Cloudy pale yellow with a tall white head.  Aroma is sweet wheat and malt.  Flavor is mild wheat and then a little sour.  Palate is refreshing and mildly sour.
Sour and sweet, light and complex.  I haven’t found any better example of Witbier yet.  One of my favourites.

Finally getting around to rating this after just having it on tap recently.  Nice cloudy yellow pour, huge frothy head.  Coriander in aroma.  Taste is what you would expect from the style - coriander, hint of banana, but very dry and altogether too watered down.  Finish is very short and crisp. For a macro, not bad, but there are far better examples of the style.

330ml bottle, room temp, bought in UK supermarket. Small, fizzy, white diminishing head, over uniformly cloudy light yellow. Aroma of oranges, coriander root, clove, digestive biscuit and yeast - no obvious hops. Medium body, fizzy (added CO2?) and chalky. Flavour has notes of coriander and orange, but really quite bland. Hard to believe this is the same beer you get on draught in Belgium (if it is). Avoid on draught in the UK - it’s served much too cold (Interbrew recommend 4C!)
black licorice, spices, bitter, and creamy.  good witbeer. small head.......
Wow, this was a good one.  Complex subtle flavors, interesting aromas.  Very distinctive and good

Pours extremely pale color, murky white. This is a good measuring stick for comparing witbiers. Not any flaws in this beer but nothing about it really stands out either. Aroma is of citrus and vanilla. Flavor and mouthfeel are dry like champagne. Nice and easy to drink.

Love the subtle tastes that exist under this beer.  The orange really makes it quite unique.  This is the best beer that I’ve found for people who don’t like beer.  It’s a great tasting beer that doesn’t taste "like beer".  It is unfortunate that so many people think that all beer tastes the same.  This is a great beer to taech them otherwise.  Only off putting thing is the cloudy look to it, but that’s where the flavour comes from so ya gotta live with it.

17 Aug 2004 Aroma: Earthy, banana & apple hop complexity. Appear: Too grey, cloudy light yellow, you can?t get much lighter colour. low retention, some suds lacing. Flovour: Bubblegum, bannana with some spice. Palate: Watery but too fizzy.

Perfect example of the style. I have tried, unsuccessfully, to clone this beer but cannot attain the subtle nuances and depth of this beer. I imagine this beer gets lower marks from other raters because of its mass market availability. If it were homebrewed in some garage and bottled by the brewers daughter I bet it would be much more received. What a shame, this beer is perfect.

The precious drink of one of my Tory friends in Britain.  Light tasting, best with an infused lemon, some of the whitest beer I’ve seen for this style.  Overall, very enjoyable, though slightly lacking the a certain bite or dimension you would desire.  Would like to have it in a normal pint glass though; the special octo-style(?) Hoegaarden glass is rather clumsy.

I referenced Hoegaarden in another review and realized I hadn’t reviewed it yet.  I hope it can forgive me because I love it.    Its just so refreshing and even looks like nice glass of lemonade.   But tastes totally unlike lemons and totally like goodness.

bottle from Freakin Frog,
cloudy crpis clean taste went great with the buffalo wings,not really a fan of witbiers but this was good, and drinkable
Soapy Gold pour with a brilliant frothy head and an original and distinctive light spice taste.  One of the finest widely distributed witbiers I have ever had.

Re-rate 2005.

Had this just after a Guinness and Smithwicks and it was easily the most flavorful of the three. The sourness in the finish is  nice and while at times it tastes a little like sour citrus fruit it is balanced by the spices so never gets unpalatable.


On tap at Yeoman’s Road Pub in Tampa. Pours a hazy gold. Yeasty fruity, hay-like aroma. Tastes of ripe fruit and spices. Great mouthfeel like all wheats, substantial while still being refreeshing.

The first time I had this beer (a long time ago now), I didn’t like it. I thought it was too soapy. But now, (a long time later) I’ve matured and learnt to appreciate the qualities of a good beer. This was a very pleasant, light-tasting beer tasting of wheat and spices, but smooth enough that the spices are still not overpowering. Two thumbs up! Thanks to RichJ7 for refreshing my memory on this one!

Bottled -- Pours a very pale straw colour, with a fantastic frothy head and decent spicy aroma. Head retention was average.
The taste of orange and coriander complement the slight wheat malty flavour ok, little bit of hoppyness. Clean and very refreshing, would have no trouble drinking large amounts of this beer.

murky light golden colour with a large fluffy head in the beginning. head decreased rapidly after initial pour. breaded yeast aroma. taste of light wheat, grains and yeast. nice lightweight enjoyable beer.
Tap. Looks like lemonaid. Citrusy wheatie aroma. Flavor is malty, with a bit of hop bitternes for balance. Citrusy and refreshing. Not bad for a summer beer, but it doesn’t look like beer...
Mmmm...a delicious wheat.  Very refreshing, with some spices and the usual wheat smells and tastes.

My first wheatbeer - i think it has changed since? It’s a very nice wheatbeer, but it’s also kindof "average" - trying not to displease anyone instead of *really* pleasing some people. Still very refreshing on a hot summer day! I could wash them down all day...
Robust aroma of apricot, banana and cloves - nothing subtle about it.  Light tan and cloudy.  Sweet apricot and clove flavor - no bitterness at all.

Looks like soft frozen lemonade...I mean it just looks like it would quench your thirst...not very complex, but a lot less spicy than its Celis White nephew...not a fan of wheat so it LOOKS more tasty and refreshing than it is...

All the classic wheat beer components are present: cloudy pour with spicy/fruity aftertaste.  Hoegaarden is less spicy and more caramel in character than Schneiders, for example.
I like a spicy wheat beer but this is still a good representation of the style.

Pours a cloudy Lemonade colour with some white head. The Aroma is clovey and spicy. The flavour starts kinda light and refreshing with little body but the spices start to kick in as you sip. Some Butter or caramel sweetness is evident. The Beer Laces well. This is one very enjoybale and refreshing beer reminiscent of Lemonade. Would go down good after a long hot day. Cheers!
Classic witbier appearance with golden-white coloring and suspended yeast.  Subtle aroma.  Definitely not as complex as micro witbiers but highly drinkable and a favorite of mine.

12 oz. brown, bowling pin shaped bottle, with snap off cap.
Best before date of 16-08-05, so pretty fresh then. Poured out a very pale golden yellow color, with lots of suspended yeast in it.
Almost white in color. Huge white, frothy head at first, but it quickly slid back to a floating island of meringue on top of the beer.
Aromas are of corriander, orange peel, wheat malts, and yeast, in that order. Tastes are of lactic wheat tang, spices, and yeast. Thin mouthfeel, not as thick feeling as it looks. Plenty of carbonation, however. Swirling the glass produces another volumous head.
Spicy tasting, and finishes sweet and sour. Fairly decent wheat beer overall.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy pale yellow/gold with a big head that slowly dissipated to a coverlet. Aroma was dominated by citrusy/lemony notes, some pine, with coriander seed becoming noticable as it warmed. Flavour was buttery lemon, tangy with some light banana notes and cloves in the background. Light bodied with very fine carbonation and very well balanced bitterness. This is a beer that compliments itself in every aspect.

Slight hoppy aroma..memories of Holsten Alkolfrei, cloudy lemon juice colour, quickly dissipating head, hints of orange and spices..like a very weak chai tea.  Not terrible, and very refreshing...I must ask though, where are my precious malts?

Cloudy pale blonde color, thin white head.  Nice aroma of citrus, maybe spices also. The flavor is mostly citrus, maybe spices too. Light to medium body, oily mouthfeel. This is a mainstream witbier, it is easily drinkable by a lot of people, but it’s not very good.
Poured a hazy/cloudy yellow with an averaged sized head. Aromas and tastes of lemons and citris. One of the best Witbiers out there. Very easy to drink...

Cloudy and pale in the glass, with a delicate white head.  Aromas of lemon and citrus, slight smell of yeast.  This beer has a diminutive taste, but is complex and very subtle -- maybe a little too subtle to appreciate the flavors and spice, however.  I expected more from this witbier.

330ml bottle.  A hazy, pale yellow witbier that pours with a foamy, lasting head.  White bread aroma with a lemony accent.  Light body with a creamy/watery mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  Bready, wheaty, and pasta-like flavour has some citrus notes.  Dry, lightly bitter finish.  Coriander and orange peel tastes aren’t particularly noticeable.  Still a relatively pleasant summer drink, but seems to have lost much of its character over the last few years.  This is the unoffensive, mainstream version of a beer that was once much better.
Very interesting beer, with a well balanced taste (and content) of yeast.  Fruity and a little bit spicy taste.
This is such a beautifull beer.Looks pale yellow contains some yeast inside.Easy drinking and fresh beer.Nice after taste.Stays in your tongue for hours.

Keg @ Akkurat, Stockholm
Served in iced glasses. Very summery drink. Mother of all wit-beers? A bit thinner than I remember, might be due to temperature.
Good white beer. Gold coloured, perfect colour. Very nice beer. Especially for long hot summer evenings. Fruity and fresh taste.
Great white color, looks good in that big Hoegaarden glas, nice yeasty citrus aroma, fresh taste. Medium body. Kind of like this beer...........sometimes.

Orangish yellow body with fluffy white head. Smells of clove, citrus and wheat. Taste is a little tart, smooth on tongue and shows more of the asaid wheat, clove and citrus tang. Pretty good white, certainly more creamy than most. Very good.

Bottle...date coded..best before date, instructions on how to pour and temp recommendation of 4 degrees Celcius. Poured a nice hazy pale milky straw color with a medium frothy cap that stayed in place for some time .

Naturally carbonated...very lively in the glass with a constant stream of bubbles streaming up the sides of the glass

. Wonderful mellow aromas of citrus peel, spice and fragrant wheat malts. Starts peppery-tart but then mellows into a silky mouth feel punctuated with the sweet-sour tastes: citus peel, coriander, crisp wheat malt tartness...excellent on the tongue. The finish is a prolonged affair where the sweet and sour tastes duke it out and the malt leaves an impression of soda crackers and lemon peel...very nice finish. I can now appreciate the reputation this grand daddy of witbeirs enjoys. There are different and some more flavorful whites but it’s hard to improve on Hoegaarden’s straight forward delivery of the main characteristics that define the witbeir style.

Reevaluated 24/7/04..on tap at EJ's this draft version really exemplifies the cloves and dry finish....served in the Hoegaarden draft tumbler 
glass the head stayed longer....very tasty and refreshing 100% better than bottled

Cloudy golden, large white head. Smells a bit soapy and florally. taste is pretty much the same, with hints of wheat, but heavily soaped without being bitter. Not a huge fan of the style, but it’s not bad.

Bottle. Nose is very yeasty and raw. Pours a dense one-finger head on a straw yellow cloudy body. Body looks like lemonade. Taste is very yeasty and wheaty. It tastes quite raw and unrefined. There is a flavor vaguely reminiscent of suntan lotion. There is a spice/clove taste on the finish. I don’t know. Not really my cup o’ tea. I like everything about it except that lotion like taste. The only other Witbier I have tried is New Belgium Sunshine Wheat, and it seemed to have alot more character.

On tap at the Beer Sellar in Nashville.  Great golden color with white head.  Floral aroma.  Citrus flavor with some clove.  Not my favorite, but ok.  Fairly palatable.  Like most Belgians, deserves a second try.

Flowery aroma.  Great yellow color with lots of sediment.  The flavor is a touch spicey with a real wheatiness.  This beer has mild amount of carbonation and a slightly sticky aftertaste.  Overall, this is a nice beer to sit back and enjoy.

Hazy, pale yellow. A floral spicy aroma.
Spicy(coriander), citrusy taste. Crisp,
clean and refreshing.

A great Belgian White. Aroma is slightly citrusy and when poured it comes out cloudy and light orange in color  while it supports a nice pure white head.
If you get the chance try it.

Bottle. Pale cloudy golden color with a big white head. Yeasty aroma with a bit of spice and green apples. Big wheat flavor with citrus, corriander and a nice mouthfeel. Clean, but there is a hunt of an aftertaste.

What a nice surprise to find this one on draft in NY’s Kennedy airport at a little place in Terminal 2!  Poured cloudy, light yellowish color with a thin white head.  Aroma is fruity, slightly sour, citrus and spice.  Flavor is pleasant, tart, yeasty, wheaty and spicey.  Medium body and lively carbonation.  Very pleasant.
One of my first Belgian whites.  I can’t really say anything that hasn’t already been said, but I like it you know.

Ah hoegaarden. Probably the first wit I ever encountered. Pleasant but I have encountered better wits. +++ This one came in a 12 oz bottle. Now that impressed me as most Belgian beer I encounter comes in an 11.2 oz bottle - so I did appreciate the slightly larger size. It poured the color of weak lemonade. Pretty sickly looking really. There was at least a small white head. The aroma was rather pleasant with reasonably strong citrus, spice an wheat elements. The texture was surprisingly dry. The flavor was nicely wheaty with spice and citrus present as well. The finish was very dry and slightly tart.

A nice creamy hazy yellow with staying head. Mostly orange and a little coriander in the aroma (duh) with some lemon and a bit of a sharp acidic smell. Flavor is soft and delicate with lots of melon qulalities and many echoes of the aroma. This stuff simply rocks, and I can’t really think of anything more refreshing to drink.

I have had this many times in the past and never rated it for some reason.  Anyway- I resampled this on tap at a local bar and it was a lot better than I had remembered from previous tastings.  Almost every aspect reminded me of my new favorite wit- victory whirlwind.  Very nice cloudy dishwater yellow with a minimal white head which fades.  Great spicy and wheaty aroma with lots of phenolic character.  Very grassy and bubblegum like with a hint of clove.  Flavor is mild yet complex with lots of spices mixing in with the wheat.  Maybe a hint of vanilla as well.  Good mouthfeel, as it is sweet and exceptionally smooth.  This wit is perhaps slightly less carbonated than others like whirlwind but it really tastes great.  One of the best mass produced beers in the world.
Lovely beer, the pinnicle of the style.  Nice orange bitter and coriander marriage of flavours.
Large white head, body cloudy. It smells like apples and banana.  Great beer overall.
Pale yellow body with a good amount of creamy white head. Wheaty lemon aroma. More lemony wheat in taste, with a grassy finish. Flavor is good, but too light.
Pours very turbid pale yellow/off white with a behemoth head.  Aroma of citrus, yeast, chardonnay, and hops.  Tastes very smooth, with citrus, Niagara white wine, hops, and yeast at the finish.
Had on tap in The Cellar, St.Andrews, Scotland.  Strong Wheat. Worth having a couple to discern taste.
12 oz bottle at Steve’s.  Benchmark Witbeer  Very refreshing on a sunny summer afternoon, but the style is just too light for me.  .

Cloudy, pale lemon color in glass, very inviting, with a dense white head that resolves without lace.  Citrus and a suprising pine note in the aroma, plus mild yeastiness.  Flavor is citrus, pine, apricot, yeast (in that order on the tongue), with apricot at the end and a very faint licorice aftertaste.  Strong carbonation, hops character is almost nonexistent.  Overall my favorite everyday drinker.

I could never get into this one. Looks pretty in the tumbler. Like lemonade with lots of backwash. Smells like chemical cleaner, but not in a bad way. Flavors are lemony, fizzy and transparent, very bland and transparent. Not the best Wit. Man back in the day the Celis White was the king of the land, much better than this one. Now they both suck.
grat

Pours a light orange/tan with a fizzy head. Aroma is mild but citrusy. Flavor is citrusy, wheaty, with a bit of spice, and some bubblegum as it warms. A very refreshing beer, I can't wait to lay out on the beach with a six pack of this. This is the kind of beer that should be in corona commercials.
Great example of a witbier. Very smooth and citrusy. Goes down easy and extremely good to drink when it is really cold. Light colored. Thirst quenching.

I love this Witbeer, I guess I’m just A witbeer fan, but I enjoy drinking this brew, It goes down easy, very fruity, And an easy drink. I understand why some don’t like it, but I’m A fan of Witbeers! I like it!
pours a light yellow with a thick white head. has a lemony wheat aroma. crisp slightly bitter flavor that isn’t bad. not my style of beer personally, but not a bad white beer.

Oh dear oh dear.  What’s all the fuss about this stuff?  I’ve never liked it, and I never will - I’m not a fan of wheat beers anyway, but sickly sweet toothrot with dodgy spices/essences... no thanks.  Horrible.
Pours a cloudy yellow-white with a thick white head. Aroma is typical for a witbiere, citrus and yeast. Taste is very mellow, smooth. Very good.

Light yellow and very cloudy color with big head. Looks very much of grape lemonade. Aroma has some lemon but banana comes out stronger. Flavor starts with crispy carbonated bite in your tongue, later taste of malt is also dominated by banana. Little bit of bland taste, and I also waited this beer to be fuller. Carbonation in the end covers some of the mild hops, although some of it works nicely. As I said this was little bit of disappointment, altough it was my first Belgian white. May work fine when you are thirsty or in sauna.
Pours a murky, lemon juice color with a little white head.  Strong citrus hop and doughy nose.  Flavors are orange (with the peel) belgian yeast, and a very feint licorice taste.  Very nice.
Still the best white beer. Good fresh citrus taste. Beautiful looks in characteristic glass!
This beer looks, smells and tastes wonderful. Cloudy, citrus-y sweet and incredibly refreshing. The perfect thirst-quencher for our hot, humid Atlanta summers.

I really wanted to like this beer as I had heard so many people rave about it.  However, I won’t be so ignorant to say it’s crap, but it sure taste’s like it.  I suffered through two bottles poured into a glass.  The head was awesome and the beer looked great, but I couldn’t stomach the taste.  I actually liked the Blue Moon Belgian White better.

Re:rate - I must have gotten a bad batch a few years back, this beer is not that bad. In fact, it’s rather tasty and refreshing. I don’t love Witbiers but this is one of the better ones.
Lightly cloudy pale golden in color with an egg white head that is modestly retained.  Aroma is spicy/yeasty.  Flavor is spicy with light wheast flavor.  Finish is dry.  Nice thirst quencher.

Alright, this where me and the import guys but heads. This is rank, one glass was enough for anyone in the room.
Out of 10 people (all of which who have had well over 200 different beers) this was not one they’d recomend. Come on, the smell alone was enough to make a horse puke. I’ll stop there. But, please, go buy a 6 of these and enjoy. For that matter, buy two 6’s, and all of you enjoy.
Super head and a nice cloudy yellow appearance.  Very nice taste with a subdued sweet citrus taste.  Aftertaste is very good as well.

(on tap) Going back this was the first witt I ever tasted, so.... Lots of foam, lots ofbanana to the nose. A big mouth for a scottish ale-lover, but I really like the fullness of a Hoegaarden. Thanx for keeping up the good work in the hard times after WW2.
Estery aroma, citrus. Cloudy light yellow color. Taste is very belgian, with wheat and floral notes. Medium body. Great witbeer.
Very light, a little too thin for my liking. The flavour that is there is nice but there’s not nearly enough of it.

this beer is very refreshing. it is really light in body, but its not light on taste. the flavour is definitely not lacking, but its not too forceful which allows it to go down smooth. i had it served to me in a giant Hoegaarden pint glass which is really heavy and looks awesome. i noticed that the head stuck around for longer than most beers. Awesome brew.
with a twist of freshly squeezed lime, this is definately one of the most refreshing beers. very light and fruity flavour, very smooth taste.

Don’t forget this one for that crisp refreshing summer cold drink.  An upscale after a sweat quick one - or two :-) - that you’ll find cloudy, pale moon yellow, a touch spiced, white headed and satifying.

A huge frothy head over a pale hazy yellow beer.  Nice carbonation retains a (thin) head throughout.  Nice aroma of spice and citrus. Initial tang of bitter and tart followed by the spiciness of coriander.  Dry and refreshing, very quenching.  Defines style.

Pale gold, very unclear, white creamy head. Good carbonation. Fresh flavour with citrus, yeast and wheat. Some underlying spicyness (coriander, and a hint of pebber?). A smooth palate. Overall a very good wit beer (prototypic).
The flavoring is very familiar to the Sterkens White I had last christmas. Spicy, carbonated flavoring. Better than Sterkens White. Looks make it resemble a very thin wheat beer. Not Bad.

Bottle- Pours a paly yellow body, with a fluffy white head. Aromas are floral, fruity, and somewhat spicy. Taste is citrus with a slight hoppy edge and a mild spice flavour. Leaves a little bit of a bite in the throat, making this beer even more interesting.
A very fine brew. Pours a deep gold with a nice white head. Taste is slightly spicy, sweet and malty. A very nice brew even though Belgian Whites aren’t really my thing.

Hazy pale straw body, creamy white head that doesn’t quit.  Dusty grain aroma with orange citrus notes.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel.  Gentle pepper, orange, and grain in the flavor.  Finishes with sort of a diluted hop bitterness.

I refer to this one as the manly beer because of the huge glasses they serve it in at the BierMarkt - you have to be a man to have more than one of those, just to lift the big glss after having a few!

Tried both on tap (Toronado) and bottled.  Bottled was better: cloudy yellow-orange color with thick fizzy head; aromas of orange and lemon; tart, a bit sweet, yeasty, nutty, and citrusy flavor. On tap, the yeast had settled so the color was clear and it had less body.  Great summer beer.

Of all white beers, this is the standard.  Nice cloudy hazy pour, mmm, smell the spices come through.
Nice balance of coriander/citrus in the finish.  
I dont get that much of a presence of sweetness in this one that many folks seem to.  Exceptional beer.

I have to admit that I’m not a big Belgian White fan, so I didn’t really expect to like this beer, and I was right.  It featured, in healthy doses, everything I dislike about this style: cloudy, dark appearance, lots of carbonation, and cloyingly sweet flavors of citrus (mostly orange/pineapple), fruit, and spice, and a lack of any noticeable hop flavors.  So I can’t say I really enjoyed it.  That said, it seemed to be an incredibly well-crafted example of this style, much more full than a Blue Moon and more flavorful than a Paulaner hefeweizen .  It had quite a bit of character, and none of its features struck me as poor or inappropriate qualities.  It’s a quality brew, but it’s simply not my type.
Smells like a White beer, looks like it. Taste is some carbonation and some of that fruit. Also honey and citrus. Could be apple, grapefruit, even spearmint.

Bottle conditioned. Spicy aroma of earthy coriander and a faint touch of vanilla, phenolic and citrus fruit. Very soft refreshing body with some acidity and a touch of chalkiness. Better the Hoegaarden on tap I’ve had.

Beautiful beer! Currently my favourite. Wonderful full white head with pleasant aftertaste.
Could drink this non stop!

Hmmmm... wasn't expecting a sweet tasting beer like this.  Thought I'd give it a try since JACK ASStor's had it on tap.  Served in a vase-like tumbler.  Very sweet.  I didn't enjoy it as much as others on this board, but that may be because it was a draught, not bottled.

The hazy yellow color is nifty.  Really spicy aroma.  Tastes of orange peel, pepper, smoke, and spices.  Hard to pick up on the hops with all the malt and yeast-based flavors in there.  Quite an interesting beer.
Pale orange, dirty color.  White head.  Blast of orange in the nose.  Flavors of orange peel, corriander, and bready malt.  Hoppy tang at the end.  Always a pleasure.
